item.title: Course Overview
item.description:
The Future of Rain Forests | IDS 2935 | Fall 2021 Wet Dirt Roads (La Tigra, Honduras). Photo by Michael Vilorio
Tropical Rain Forests cover approximately 15% of the Earth’s land surface but contain over 50% of the world’s biodiversity. They are also the home to millions of people, the source of products central to our lives, shape global climate, and are being cleared at unprecedented rates.

item.title: GenEd Info
item.description: General Educations Designations for IDS 2935 (Rain Forests) Primary Designation: Biological Sciences Secondary Designation (if seeking): International (N) A minimum grade of C is required for general education Writing designation: No writing designation Photo by Chris Curry.

item.title: Course Meetings, Location, & Weekly Schedule
item.description: Meeting Day, Time, & Location: Tuesday Period 4 (10:40 AM - 11:30 AM) in AND101 AND Thursday Period 4-5 (10:40 AM - 12:35 PM) in WM 0202 Weekly Schedule WHY ARE WE FASCINATED BY TROPICAL RAIN FORESTS? Week 1 24-Aug Introduction to each other and the course. What is a ‘tropical rain forest’? 26-Aug Where do stereotypes about rain forests come from?

item.title: biosci & Quest 2 SLOs
item.description: Biological Sciences SLOs: Students will be able to… Quest 2 SLOs: Students will be able to… This Course’s SLOs: Students will be able to… Assessment: Student competencies will be assessed through… Identify, describe, and explain the basic concepts, theories and terminology of natural science and the scientific method; the major scientific discoveries and the impacts on society and the environment; and the relevant processes that govern biological and physical systems.
